2020spring.name: Design of Useful and Usable Interactive Systems

projects.name: Automated Course Scheduling
description: A full-stack web app that digitizes and automates various components of the course scheduling process.

I worked closely with another classmate and my high school's administration to improve efficiency during the course selection period. It was built primarily in Node.js, was hosted on Firebase, and processed a ~50-page spreadsheet of course information and class period availability as input.

projects.name: Personal Site
description: A website showing and documenting various parts of my personal and professional life.

I originally wrote this as a pure HTML/CSS/JS site but rewrote it entirely with React a few months later. I had only really started coding the previous year, so this site served as a great way to learn React and frontend web development.
Since then, I've enjoyed updating this site every so often to accommodate different forms of content, undergo new design changes, as well as to document parts of my life.
Also, I'm aware that the mobile experience right now isn't too great. Hang tight, I'm working on it!

projects.name: RoommateHub
description: An iOS app serving as a centralized hub for roommates with features including roommate profiles, embedded messaging, and shared task lists.

I wrote RoommateHub with another classmate for our CS 50 final project. I learned a lot about writing a multi-page app in Swift using UIKit and leveraging Firebase to handle secure authentication and database management.

As an Apple fanboy, the euphoria I got (and still get) from using well designed and executed Mac and iOS apps is what drove me to start programming in the first place. As a result, getting to collaborate with a close friend on all aspects of our own iOS app (ideation, UI/UX design, system design, implementation) was an incredible experience.

projects.name: FoodSpace
description: A full-stack web app that streamlines the process of ordering food. Integrating the Yelp Fusion API, users can find restaurants based on various criteria and schedule meal times on their calendar based on the hours for that specific place and time.

I wrote FoodSpace at home following my first semester at college. It was a fairly simple web project, but at the time, it helped me learn more about backend development in Node.js, HTTP requests between the server and client, and calling external APIs.

projects.name: MiniML
description: A series of Turing-complete interpreters for a subset of the OCaml programming language following the substitution, lexically-scoped environment, and dynamically-scoped environment semantic models. MiniML displays a graphical REPL on the command line, where users can issue OCaml commands to be executed by all three interpreters.

I wrote this as my CS 51 final project. For about ten days, my life revolved solely around MiniML, and loose paper sketches of semantic model implementation mimicked legos around my room when I was a kid. The project gave me a more in-depth understanding of OCaml and its underlying principles, such as functional semantics, environment models, and type checking.

Somewhat ironically (or not so ironically), the project also gave me a greater appreciation for the language features I didn't have time to support, such as sugaring, references, and lazy computation.

projects.name: ML-Enabled Spotify Curator
description: A full-stack web application using k-means clustering to help users discover new songs they love. After signing in with their Spotify credentials, users can enter any number of songs, and the app will return the probability that they will like each entered song, based on the musical attributes (energy, tempo, instrumentalness, etc.) of their previously liked songs.

I worked on this project with a friend. He implemented most of the ML model and the frontend, and I handled implementing the backend and stringing everything together. This project gave me the chance to practice my backend development, and I also learned about setting up distributed task queues with Celery and using Redis as a message broker transport and result store to deploy the ML model asynchronously.

projects.name: Article Bias Chrome Extension
description: A chrome extension that will use NLP to detect political biases in articles.
I'll be interning here this summer, working on backend development.

At Cisco, the team I'm on develops with Webex Media Engine (WME), a cross-platform multimedia SDK serving Webex Meetings and Teams. Currently, I'm working on implementing a testing framework in C++ for WME's Acoustic Echo Canceler for macOS and Windows builds.
I've previously completed projects in these two areas:

WME Media Quality Data Pipeline: I worked on projects in multiple stages on the pipeline, such as debugging WME code in C++, working with a few other teammates from China to implement and deploy ElasticSearch data aggregation scripts with Python and Airflow, and creating interactive Kibana dashboards to visualize and monitor key quality and performance metrics. These projects and dashboards have helped our team better monitor WME performance and more quickly spot troubling trends.

WME Internal Debug and Triage Tools: I implemented new and updated existing automation and analyzer scripts in Python and have built multiple Jenkins pipelines to allow more engineers within Webex to leverage them. The tools save WME engineers many hours each day by automating frequent processes such as searching and downloading call logs and crash reports, detecting errors and abnormalities in them, and triaging them into relevant problem categories.

research.company: Harvard Cloud Networking and Systems Group
description: I'm working under Professor Minlan Yu and am researching how to leverage RPC system queues to identify network performance issues such as noisy neighbor effects and head-of-line blocking.
